column3: A simple weave, with each poi doing one downbeat on opposite sides of the body
column4: Try to keep the poi perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the sides of your body
column5: As you get more comfortable, try to spin slower
column6: It is encouraged to learn both the "left hand over" & "right hand over" variations (refer to video)
column7: Dont be afraid to exaggerate your arm movements as much as possible so you dont hit yourself when the poi crosses to the other side (applies to all other weaves and n beat moves)

column3: Both poi spin in the same direction in split time to the side of the body
column4: Try to keep the poi perpendicular to the floor and parallel to each other
column5: The poi should be spinning in split time; when one poi is pointing down, the other is pointing up
column6: Its easier to start learning the move with shorter poi; we can do this by partially wrapping the poi in our arms (applies to corkscrew)

column3: Same time, same direction done with both hands together
column4: The planes of each hand are on a slight slant to prevent the poi from hitting each other
column5: Start with your hands farther apart and work your way to getting them right next to each other
column6: It may be easier to learn the move in split time first so the poi dont hit each other, then purposely let the timing sync up until you get into same time

column3: Both poi switch spin direction through the turning the body
column4: Point your wrists down while turning
column5: This move is in same time so both poi should point downwards at the same time
column6: Practice two beat spins with either hand pointing to either the left or the ride side of your body until you are able to move the motions closer to your body (applies to windmill and watermill)

column3: A two beat weave done in floor plane
column4: Your hands should be pointing in opposite directions at all times
column5: Imagine each poi making a figure 8, alternating between top and bottom. Additioanlly, one poi always follows the other's path.

column3: A wrap that hits the forearm
column4: Aim to hit your arm an inch above the top of the glowstick; there's a sweet spot that shouldn't hurt your arm

column3: A simple weave, with each poi doing one downbeat on one side of the body and two downbeats on the opposite side of the body
column4: Try to keep the poi perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the sides of your body
column5: As you get more comfortable, try to spin slower
column6: This also applies to 2 beat weaves, but imagine each poi tracing the lines of an "X" when they go in front of you

column3: Similar to the 3 beat weave, but in reverse
column4: This is the only move that has a "reverse" page because it is usually the first move you learn in reverse. Almost every move after this has a reverse version.

column3: A two beat weave done above the head in wall plane
column4: Because this is one of the first moves that is learned in wall plane, it will take time to get used to spinning your poi without slanting
column5: One of the most difficult parts of this move is getting it into split time. Count beats in your head if it helps.
column6: Most of the move should be done through wrist movement
column7: You can do same time shoulder reels first, and then purposely let the timing unsync untill you get into split time (applies to hip reels in watermill)

column3: A windmill, but the front beats are opened up
column4: Opening the arms up may feel uncomfortable, but you can practice it with one hand at a time

column3: A windmill by the hips
column4: Both wrists should point inward when the poi goes behind you
column5: Make sure that the timing is split time. You can count in your head for this.

column3: A combination of a hip and shoulder reel turns
column4: Both poi should be in same time (downbeats are at the same time)
column5: Be comfortable with reel turns

column3: A wrap that hits the bicep
column4: Make sure that your arm is bent perpendicular to your body (not outwards)

column3: A wrap that hits the shin
column4: Balance. Goes well with a side of chicken (wrap)!

column3: A combination of the forward and reverse 3 beat and windmill
column4: A difficult part of this move is the transition from r3b to windmill. If you end your r3b in front of you, the windmill should start behind you and vice versa.
column5: Spend as much time as you need at each section of the fountain. You can always cut down how long you spend at each part as you get more comfortable.

column3: A wrap where both poi converge around the hands
column4: Both poi should be spinning in the same direction with wall planes bent slightly inward
column5: When entering a spiral wrap, let go of the string between your fingertips so it can naturally wrap around your hands

column3: A wrap that hits the tricep behind the body
column4: Shove your arm behind you (pretend you are elbowing someone) and wrap on your tricep)

column3: A movement with poi that restricts movement to the bottom half of the spin
column4: This move is relatively simple, but takes a lot of practice to clean. Keep the pendulums as controlled as you can.
column5: swing swong

column3: A 3 petal antispin flower done with each hand, pointed outwards from the center
column4: Frontals are a two downbeat move. If you count when the poi faces downwards (6 o'clock) you should be able to count 2 per cycle.
column5: Frontals are one of the first moves people learn that allow them to practice against a wall; if you do so managing planes becomes way easier.

column3: A combination of both hands doing bicep wraps on top of the arms
column4: Your arms must be perpendicular to your body when performing bicep wraps can VB vn
column5: Most of the movement comes from the wrists so focus on wrist movement

column3: A combination of both hands doing bicep wraps below the arms
column4: Your arms must be perpendicular to your body when performing bicep wraps
column5: Most of the movement comes from the wrists so focus on wrist movement

column3: A figure 8 drawn with crossed arms in wall plane
column4: Both hands are each doing a two beat but are on opposite sides of the body
column5: Each poi should alternate between being in front of your body and behind
column6: Practice with one poi wrapped in your hand at a time

column3: A two petal flower where the direction of spin of the poi is the same as the movement of the arm
column4: Both "spins" within the inspin should be on a cardinal. Keep the spins controlled!

column3: Crossers, but with the front beats opened up (similar to vitruvian)
column4: Both of your arms at some point should be full extended, with the other bent.
column5: Each arm should alternate tracing the other arm

column3: A 3 petal antispin flower hybrid with an extension
column4: Draw an equilateral triangle with your hand and make sure to accentuate the top petal
column5: Focus on always having equidistance from your belly button to either bottom petal. At first, it will result in smaller triquetras, but when you are more comfortable you can increase the size of the pattern.

column3: A 4 petal antispin flower that hits each cardinal direction
column4: The most important part of this move is to make sure that each cardinal direction is properly aligned
column5: It may help to practice in front of a mirror
column6: 4 petal antispins have 3 downbeats, similar to how a triquetra has 2 downbeats. You should be able to count 3 times when the poi head points downwards

column3: A fountain similar to a regular 4x4 fountain but backward
column4: There is only one beat for each hand per cardinal direction
column5: imagine alternating between forward and reverse 2 beat weaves, except you change the levels of your hands
column6: If your doing this move correctly your hands will alternate between right and left on top when you pass through the middle

column3: A combination of half an antispin and an extension
column4: Pretend you are only doing half of an antispin and do an extension back to where your hand started
column5: Bend your arms slightly

column3: A body tracer combining parts of a snake and an extension
column4: This hard part of this move is the same as the movement for a snake. If you are having trouble with this move, try learning the snake first.
column5: Each hand should be alternating cycles (one hand tucks in front of you while the other tucks behind you)

column3: Both poi spin in the same direction and meet up on the left and right, but the hands move in opposite directions.
column4: Focus on getting the east and west cardinal lined up

column3: A sequence of pendulums that don't require you to move your hand
column4: Align both pendulums such that they create a straight line

column3: A combination of pendulums and parts of antispins
column4: If you are comfortable with pendulums, focus on the timing and try to get the top pendulum in sync

column3: Both poi tangle and are pulled to create a fast spinning buzzsaw
column4: The point at which the strings tangle should be the same distance from the poi/handle
column5: If you look at orbitals/ airwraps/ hyperloops from the side, you will notice that the poi paths arent parallel. One poi is slightly skewed so that theres a greater chance of the poi being able to cross paths and initiate the tangle.

column3: Both poi tangle and untangle in wall plane
column4: The point at which the strings tangle should be the same distance from the poi/handle
column5: Don't try to force the untangle; if your planes are correct, they should untangle automatically

column3: A weave that involves spinning poi behind the back
column4: This move requires a lot of practice with each hand separately
column5: Try keeping one poi spin behind you in wall plane without hitting anything
column6: You will hit yourself less if you turn your torso more

column3: A body tracer behind your back, along the arm
column4: It may be difficult to contort your body but try to get the poi in same time to make the move look clean

column3: A mercedes (triquetra) done along with a pendulum instead of an extension
column4: Align the pendulum such that it creates a straight line with the top petal of the triquetra

column3: Two antispin flowers spinning in the same direction that cross over and extend back
column4: Much of the difficulty from this move comes from the potential of the poi hitting each other or tangling. Note that the poi should be on slightly different wall planes
column5: Each hand performs a complete antispin before extending back.

column3: Two antispin flowers spinning in opposite directions that alternate extensions
column4: Practice each hand separately. It is important that you can do at least one hand without thinking so you can focus on the other.

column3: Triquetras that follow the hand path of a static spin
column4: You need to be comfortable with performing extremely fast triquetras
column5: The static spinning poi follows the same path as the triquetra arm (both the arm and the poi should be right next to each other)

column3: An extended airwrap
column4: The point at which the strings tangle should be the same distance from the poi/handle
column5: You can sustain the tangle by rotating your arms in the same direction the poi are moving
column6: If you spin slower than normal, the extry + exit motion becomes easier to process (it usually happens p fast)

column3: A normal C CAP, but with a snake variant instead of an extension
column4: If you are familiar with other body tracers such as snakes, this move combines a simple body tracer with a CAP

column3: An antispin inspin hybrid, with parts of it behind the body
column4: Both the antispin and inspin are performed behind you at the same time at a point in the move. Get comfortable with performing flowers behind you!
column5: Dont be afraid to extend your arms up + out as much as possible to make sure both flowers dont hit each other. Also find a big area with a tall ceiling to practice this move.

column3: A one petal vertical flower
column4: Your hand should follow the path of a static spin

column3: A form of a CAP that goes through each C CAP for each cardinal
column4: Practice each CAP (northern, eastern, western, and southern) separately
column5: One hand performs a normal 4 petal antispin while the other focuses on CAPs

column3: Both poi spin in opposite directions and make a zigzag pattern crossing each cardinal
column4: Practice antispins with varying speeds

column3: Both hands spin in opposite directions and form a northern and southern triangle
column4: You need to be very comfortable with antispins to be able to be able to perform this move

column3: The rotation of the poi such that the hand follows the path of the poi. Looks like a static spin, but is significantly harder.
column4: Your hand and poi should both be rotating about a center point

column3: A one petal horizontal flower
column4: This move is much more difficult that cateyes because of gravity is actively working against you
column5: Your hand should follow the path of a static spin
